p: Risk perception of COVID-19 may influence individuals’ engagement in sexual activity during the pandemic. Risk perception of COVID-19 refers to people’s intuitive evaluations of how likely they are to contract COVID-19 [ 17]. According to stage theory, risk perception acts as a trigger for precautionary action [ 18]. Leung et al. reported that people with higher risk perceptions of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) were more likely to take comprehensive precautionary measures against infection [ 19]. The fear of contagion itself may reduce physical contact within couples, from simple kissing to full sexual intercourse [ 14]. If the risk perception is excessive, particularly when a person is overwhelmed with negative SARS-related information, it will lead to irrational fear [ 20].
